awd_titl_txt: Developing Educational Pathways to Credentials in Plastics Engineering Technology
awd_abstract_narration:
Industries in the United States that use plastic injection molding to make products have a growing need for technicians who are well-skilled in the science and engineering of plastics manufacturing. Nationwide, few technician education programs offer specific credentials in plastics engineering technologies. To prepare technicians with the desired knowledge and skills, Central Community College will partner with industry to develop and deliver the first certificate program in plastics engineering technology in Nebraska. The college will also use the new coursework to enhance its associate degree program in advanced manufacturing. The enhanced advanced manufacturing program will be designed to include pathways to help existing workers, underrepresented minorities, and veterans obtain the skills needed for jobs in plastics-related manufacturing. The project will therefore help strengthen the manufacturing workforce in this technology area for Nebraska and the nation.

The goal of the project is to increase the number of qualified technicians with skills in plastics engineering technology to meet the increasing workforce demands. The proposed curriculum in plastics engineering technology will emphasize the operation of injection molding presses, knowledge about implementing molding techniques, and improving the quality and productivity of molding processes. The project will gather input from a Business and Industry Leadership Team to ensure that the developed curriculum incorporates industry-relevant skills. The identified skills will be used as the foundation in creating four new courses on plastics engineering. These courses will be integrated into the existing advanced manufacturing degree program, and also lead to a stand-alone certificate in plastics engineering technology. A Plastics Technology Learning Laboratory will also be established. This facility will incorporate state-of-the-art equipment to promote student learning through authentic, hands-on problems in a work-like setting. Alternative course scheduling options for the curriculum, including short-term intensive workshops or courses, will be offered to increase accessibility to students, including incumbent workers and veterans. The project will also develop opportunities for existing workers or other potential students to receive credit for their existing knowledge, skills, or experience. This credit for prior learning could be applied toward the certificate or the associate degree. The project evaluation will investigate the influence of alternative scheduling and credit for prior learning within the advanced manufacturing program as well as document the project's effect on increasing the skills of technicians for the workplace. The curricular materials will be available on the project website and linked to other resource libraries for broad dissemination. This project is funded by the Advanced Technological Education program that focuses on the education of technicians for the advanced-technology fields that drive the nation's economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The Plastics-Related, Innovative Manufacturing Education (PRIME) at Central Community College (CCC) in Columbus, Nebraska focused on increasing the number of qualified plastics engineering technology technicians to meet workforce demands in Nebraska and surrounding areas for high-demand, high-wage occupations.  This was done by developing a new plastics engineering technology certificate and related courses in close collaboration with industry partners. 

PRIME has been continually guided by three objectives: 1) to develop and utilize a Business and Industry Leadership Team (BILT) to act as a resource in all facets of the program including curriculum development, equipment selection, funding, professional development and career awareness, 2) to establish plastics engineering technology programming that fully meets industry needs and provides multiple educational access points for students, and 3) to enroll non-traditional and underrepresented students through unique recruitment and scheduling strategies.  Also, PRIME focused on incumbent workers with an intent to move workers into credit bearing courses and degree/certificate programs.

During PRIME’s work, the team built and enhanced vital links between regional industry and the faculty who educate their workforce. The intellectual merit of the PRIME efforts resided in the highly engaged business and industry partnership, hands on learning in a truly national model state-of-the-art laboratory facility; the strategic alignment of credit coursework and short-term educational opportunities with industry credentials; and a resultant new national model certificate in Plastics Engineering Technology. Working closely with the BILT, the PRIME project also utilized innovative recruitment methods for students, which included alternative scheduling and collaboration with businesses and industry to help students to be on a program trajectory for the advanced skills needed for their career and jobsite. 

The specific PRIME program successes included the following:

Four plastics manufacturing courses that were fully conceptualized, co-designed and co-developed with business and industry. These courses are called Injection Molding Foundations, Injection Molding Concepts, Injection Molding Operations, and Injection Molding Processes.  These four courses make up our Plastic Engineering Technology Certificate and are fully laddered into the degree program of Advanced Manufacturing and Design Technology (AMDT).

Numerous workshops for incumbent workers were held each year by the PRIME team, including on the business and industry related topics of Fundamentals of Systematic Molding, Injection Molding Essentials, Master Molder I, and Injection Molding Essentials.  These workshops also were used to help students to springboard directly into the four courses.

Each of PRIME courses and workshops were taught within the new state-of-the-art technician training facility, called the Plastics Injection Molding and Manufacturing Laboratory.  The facility received over $300,000 of leveraged contributions by both CCC and the BILT partners.  There were also equipment discounts provided by many companies, and four major injection molding machine manufacturers also loaned the laboratory new injection molding machines.

•  PRIME’s curriculum is fully documented and shareable. It has already been shared freely with other community colleges, frequently via collegial contacts made at conferences such as at the Advanced Technological Education Conference, and the High Impact Technology Exchange Conference.  The curriculum is also based upon 65 Knowledge, Skills, and Abilities (KSAs), that were co-developed with the BILT.

Many different tours of the PRIME facility and programs were done each year by the team, including with state legislators, area school districts, businesses, industries, state and national associations, and numerous colleagues from other colleges from around the country. The PRIME team also collaborated closely with the new National Center for Next Generation Manufacturing, where PRIME also assisted with their professional development for high schools and colleges from around the country.

The voices of participants have recognized how very powerful this program has been in their own career trajectory. Here are a few quotes from recent participants:

“I have learned more in this short period of time taking these classes than I have in being a technician during the past 2 years.”

“I have learned a lot, and CCC is the only place locally that provides a plastics course that is not a 4-year program”

“I was able to add Master Molder to my resume, and to get an engineering related job”

“I was able to apply for a better job and I now help to manage injection molding projects”

“I was able to get better opportunities in my life, while learning the process to mold parts and to learn about the use of plastics all over the World”.

Finally, PRIME evolved into a model STEM educational program, that was deeply collaborative and partnered with business and industry.  It is also now fully sustained by CCC and will continue for many years. Future students and the nation itself, will benefit from all the work of the PRIME team at Central Community College as more students chose plastics engineering technology careers.


Last Modified: 01/20/2024
Modified by: Douglas R Pauley
